title: Shorthand parameter names
question: When passing a closure as a function parameter, which of these statements are true?
hint: You either list your parameters and return value, or you use shorthand syntax - Swift won't allow you to use both.

correct.answer: Swift can infer the parameters the closure accepts.
Swift can infer the return type.
If there is only one line of code, you can skip writing return
Shorthand parameters are written as $0, $1 and so on.
When using shorthand parameters you don't list the parameters you accept.
correct.reason: This is correct. In fact, trying to list the parameters will cause an error.

correct.answer: Swift automatically provides the $ variables; we don't define them ourselves.

wrong.answer: Shorthand syntax can only be used with integers.
wrong.reason: It works fine with all data types.

wrong.answer: Shorthand syntax provides up to three parameters automatically.
wrong.reason: It provides as many as are needed.

wrong.answer: Shorthand syntax can only be used with Swift's built-in functions like print()
wrong.reason: It works fine with all functions, even ones we write.

wrong.answer: Shorthand parameters are written as #0, #1, and so on.
wrong.reason: They are written using $0, $1, and so on.

wrong.answer: You must always list the parameters you accept when using shorthand syntax.
wrong.reason: You must never do this; Swift does not let you use both.

wrong.answer: Shorthand parameters can't be used with string interpolation.
wrong.reason: They work fine with string interpolation.
